nodes.bodyText: Should the length of action and conditions always be the same? If so, I think we can have one List here where RBACEngine is an inner class that contains RBAC.Action and ImmutableMap<String, Expr>. That might make the structure clearer.
Good point! Thanks for the advice :)

You can just use variable name rbac here otherwise rbacPolicy.getPolicies() looks a bit weird to me.
Also can we use range-based for loop hereI as well(like you did for the map)?
Yes!
You can directly generate an ImmutableMap using ImmutableMap.Builder. No need to create one from Map.
Sounds good!
nit: range-based loop.
Ok, will fix!
nit: avoid using vague names like "entry", etc.

nit:
authorizationDecision = this.action.get(i) == RBAC.Action.ALLOW ? AuthorizationDecision.Decision.ALLOW : AuthorizationDecision.Decision.DENY
when action is unknown, we will need to return a unknownPolicyNames; when action is allow/deny, we will need matchingPolicyNames. So actually we just need one list here.

The reason I separate these two lists here is for a particular case when some conditions are matched and some conditions are unknown. If so, we would want to store matchedPolicy and unknownPolicy separately and always check if matchedPolicy is empty first. If matchedPolicy isn't empty, it means that there is at least a match, so we would return matchedPolicy and ignore unknownPolicy no matter if there are unknown conditions or not.
OK. This sounds good. Thanks for the clarification!
I would prefer return an empty list in order to address that there is no matching policy in this case.
OK. SG!

nit: shall we change this variable name to policyNames? CEL expression is used to check if matches. At the level of authorization engine, we might not need to use the term matching, to avoid confusion.

nodes.bodyText: Can we use some other names for authContext? such as authzStr, or decisionStr, etc.
Yes, I will change it to authzStr.
Can we directly use RBAC.Conditions here? If so, we probably can avoid creating our own map and can just use whatever provided by RBAC.
RBAC only offers a policy map (reference). However, we only need policy's condition field, so I'm assuming we have to create our own condition map here?

Eventually we don't need RbacEngine.
AuthorizationEngine just need to keep two InternalAuthorzationPolicy proto (allowPolicy and denyPolicy).
During constructor of AuthorizationEngine:

if input is Envoy RBAC, we just convert to InternalAuthorzationPolicy
if input is InternalAuthorzationPolicy, we just store input internally.

In Evaluate(), we just first iterate denyPolicy then allowPolicy.
For now, let's keep as it is.
Once my design is signed off, I will make a PR for the AuthorizatioPolicy proto.
Interpreter will be created for every CEL evaluation checking. Let's move it outside of the loop.
Sounds good!

As far as I understand, the design of part is still ongoing yet. In this PR, we can assume evaluate function takes the activation and gRPC stack will set it directly(so in this PR we don't have to deal with that EvaluateArgs<ReqT, RespT> args anymore).
@jiangtaoli2016 Feel free to correct me if this is not our current plan. Thanks!
Does it mean we can change the function signature to public AuthorizationDecision evaluate(Activation activation) for now?

I would keep the current API, i.e.,
AuthorizationDecision evaluate(EvaluateArgs<ReqT, RespT> args)
Also keep the extractFields -- so that we can test it.
Sounds good!
why protected ? Also related to whether AuthorizationEngine can be final or needs to be extended. If final this method can be final or private

Currently there is no open-sourced CEL library in Java, so all the APIs used in Authorization Engine is from a mock Cel Library interface that only holds the function signature. Therefore, I had to use Mockito to mock the behavior of helper functions in order to test the logic of evaluate function on top of that. With that being said, all the helper functions are set to protected for now, so that they can be exposed for testing, but we will change it once CEL library is open sourced in the future.
if matches is only used once, can we move it to the evaluate logic? It might simplify the logic to handle IncompleteData.

The evaluate function is more like evaluating the RBAC condition list input by the user and outputting the authorization decision, whereas the matches function handles evaluation of CEL expression and returns the eval result generated by CEL library. Thus, I think it would be more clear and readable to separate these two functions because they have different purposes. What do you think?
Maybe we could rename matches if it's confusing?
I separated this matches function also because in the unit test, I have to mock the behavior of matches in order to test the behavior of evaluate function.

I guess you can also mock interpretable.eval(...) to achieve similar purposes, right?
IMO, generally it is probably not a good idea to change the code structures to make the testing easier, unless you really have to. Also making this function protected also raised a bit of my concern(I guess you make it for testing purposes as well).
But honestly I am not sure about this as well. We can keep it as what it is right now, and see if other reviewers have any suggestions on that.
Sure, thanks for pointing it out tho!

protected is for subclasses and AFAICS there aren't any. May be package-private vs private is the issue? Also my personal preference is to split code into multiple functions for modularity/testability.
matches can be static since it doesn't use any instance vars of AuthorizationEngine?
The function matches will be changed to a private function in the future.

Now when there is a match, we will only return the policy that first matches and return it in a list. So if there is a match, we will do an early stop and return a list containing only 1 item. We might also want to slightly change the logic we check the RBACs(So we will first check the first RABC, if it's undecided, then the result would be the decision of second RBAC). You can checkout the latest design details in @jiangtaoli2016 's doc, or check with Elizabeth. Please LMK if you have any questions. Thanks!

Once you have allowEngine and denyEngine. See discussion above. The evaluation logic is as follows:
First iterate denyEngine's map (could be empty map). If there is match, immediately return deny. If there are unknown results, return undecided. If all non-match, we iterate allowEngine.
Once we enter allowEngine, if there is a match, immediately return allow. In the end of iteration, if there are unknown rules, return undecided. If all non-match, return deny.
The above logic is the same regardless if the constructor takes 1 or 2 RBAC rules.
Since we don't allow changing the policyNames, use ImmutableList
